race.name: Gravel Locos
race.tagline: Fast Texas gravel. River crossings. Scorching heat. The Unbound tune-up that breaks people.

vitals.county: Hamilton County (northern edge of Texas Hill Country)
vitals.field_size: Deep pro field (Gomez Gagne, Barrow, etc.) plus large amateur turnout - key Unbound tune-up
vitals.start_time: Hico, Texas (cowboy town associated with Billy the Kid)
vitals.registration: La Loca 150 is COMPLETELY FREE with donation-driven fundraising for Hico first responders
vitals.aid_stations: Multiple well-stocked. 2022 had one run out of water after 3B climbs - riders waited 30+ minutes.
vitals.cutoff_time: Not strictly enforced but heat and water logistics are bigger constraints
vitals.distance_options: La Loca ~157 mi (FREE), La Gran Piedra ~110 mi, La Mediana ~70 mi, La Pequeña ~30 mi

climate.primary: Texas Hill Country late May - heat is the primary challenge
climate.description: Late May means starting warm and climbing into 80s-90s°F with high sun. 2022's Wahoo reading of 120°F on fresh tarmac shows how brutal heat reflection can be.
challenges: Heat and sun on open ranch roads
Dehydration risk is the primary concern
One aid station ran out of water in 2022

terrain.primary: Smooth, fast Hill Country gravel with endless rollers
terrain.surface: 'Gorgeous' wildflower-lined gravel roads and fast limestone surfaces. 'Smooth' and 'perfect for gravel' per riders. Some chunkier patches but no singletrack or rock gardens.
features: Open ranch roads with little shade

logistics.explanation: Ted King describes "scorching heat, a stacked international field" showing up for mass starts, but the infrastructure holds. Highway 220 construction still adds delays, and you need to arrive by 6:30 am for parking at Bosque River RV Park. Packet pickup runs Friday 4-8 pm or Saturday morning 6-7:30 am. Over 1,000 riders funnel through tiny Hico—it works, but don't expect seamless execution.

length.explanation: At 157 miles, this delivers maximum suffering. Elite Julien Gagne "made a bold solo move from a group of 10 with 60 miles to go" and held it—meaning 60 miles of solo racing after already covering nearly 100. Justine Barrow "ended up riding the last 40 km solo" after thinning out her group. The distance creates race-defining moves that simply aren't possible in shorter events.

technicality.explanation: Kevin Benkenstein counted "approximately 7,000 corners" but notes "the gravel here is solid and fast." Jonas Orset describes hitting "steep kickers—200 meters with about 15% average" where "I drop to my lowest gear and pedal as hard as I can, but the bike barely moves." It's more about power than bike handling—painful climbing, not technical complexity.

elevation.explanation: The notorious "Three B's" climbs define this race. Jonas Orset describes the reality: "Bam—we hit the first of three kickers. Cadence sits at 40." Another rider notes "2,500 m in 250 km is a lot of climbing when it's all short, steep kickers." The 7,884 feet comes via relentless punchy climbs that break groups apart, not sustained mountain passes.

climate.explanation: Justine Barrow called it "hands down the hottest race I've ever done—nothing like I've experienced before." Temperature readings hit 91°F/33°C with Jonas Orset's computer showing "close to 40°C." He describes feeling "like a roasted chicken, sizzling on a grill" until river crossings provided salvation. Late May Texas heat creates race-defining conditions.

altitude.explanation: Hico sits in the Central Texas lowlands, 70 miles northwest of Waco—this is flatland country elevation-wise. You're not dealing with any meaningful altitude effects here, just standard sea-level to low-elevation racing. The 'elevation' in this race comes from climbing hills, not starting high. Your lungs won't notice the altitude, but they'll sure as hell notice the effort.

adventure.explanation: Water crossings, backup routes for flooding, limited cell service, and grades that hit 20%—this race delivers genuine adventure elements. SAG support exists for major mechanicals only, meaning you'd better be self-sufficient when things go sideways. Racing alongside pros like Peter Stetina and Ted King adds legitimacy, while the remote Central Texas location ensures you're properly isolated from civilization. It's real adventure, not manufactured hardship.

prestige.explanation: The race "stamped on the gravel map in 2021 when it debuted with a star studded start list." Ted King notes the "stacked international field" with "most of the international talent arriving in the US ahead of Gravel Locos for a pre-Unbound shakeout." Justine Barrow called it "the perfect tune-up for Unbound Gravel." Growing rapidly as a must-do pre-Unbound test.

race_quality.explanation: Well-organized with multiple distance options and proper aid stations. The heat challenges logistics but organizers adapt. Good vibes despite (because of?) the suffering.

experience.explanation: Fast racing on smooth gravel with the ever-present heat threat. River crossings add memorable moments. The shared suffering in Texas heat creates strong race stories. You'll remember it.

community.explanation: Kevin Benkenstein describes the post-race scene: "The cookout last night in town was an awesome experience after a hard day." The race raises money for Hico Volunteer Fire Department, funding "a new truck and a firehouse." Race founder Fabian built this "from scratch, from a small event in central Texas to one of the most prestigious in the country" in just three years.

field_depth.explanation: The 2024 field included "half of the top 20 men and women hailing from outside of the United States." Elite women like Justine Barrow and Marisa Boaz rode solo for long stretches due to the competitive separation. Ted King describes racing in "a highly competitive international field" where "team tactics are shaping today's gravel scene." Deep talent at the front.

value.explanation: The race "attracts riders of all skill levels, from seasoned pros to casual cyclists" with multiple distance options from 34 to 157 miles. Post-race meals are prepared by the Hico Volunteer Fire Department, and the event spans a full weekend with Friday pre-rides with pros. You get professional-level racing infrastructure in an affordable Texas town setting.

expenses.explanation: Central Texas keeps costs manageable—small town accommodations and food remain affordable. Multiple riders mention staying in the area without expense complaints. The race raises funds locally for the fire department, indicating strong community support that likely keeps vendor costs reasonable. Texas accessibility via DFW airport makes travel straightforward for most participants.

biased_opinion.summary: Gravel Locos is what happens when you make a 150-mile Unbound tune-up free. Pros use it as their final rehearsal. Amateurs get to ride with them on gorgeous Texas gravel for zero entry fee. The catch? Texas heat that can hit 120°F and aid stations that occasionally run dry.
strengths: It's FREE: La Loca 150 costs $0 with donations to first responders
Pro field: Major Unbound tune-up with international winners
The gravel: 'Smooth' and 'perfect' limestone Hill Country roads
weaknesses: Texas heat: 2022 had 120°F tarmac readings and a dry aid station
Distance: 157 miles is serious even without heat
Hico logistics: 'Middle of nowhere' Texas requires planning
biased_opinion.bottom_line: If you want a legitimate 150-mile gravel race for free with pro-level competition and legendary Texas hospitality, Gravel Locos delivers. Just train for heat.
biased_opinion.quote: 'It exceeded all of my expectations… beautiful views, fast gravel roads, and excellent race support. What else could you possibly want?' - Reddit rider

final_verdict.one_liner: Free 150-mile Unbound tune-up on gorgeous Texas gravel where Texas heat is the great equalizer.
final_verdict.should_you_race: Yes if you want a legitimate ultra-gravel experience for free with international competition and legendary Texas hospitality. Gravel Locos proves you don't need a $250 entry fee to have a world-class gravel race. Just train for heat.
final_verdict.alternatives: If you want similar distance with mud risk: Unbound. If you want Texas gravel with less heat: wait for fall events. If you want free racing: this is the gold standard.

logistics.airport: Dallas-Fort Worth (DFW) - 'a few hours' drive. Hico is 'the middle of nowhere.'
logistics.lodging_strategy: Many camp - Gravel Locos offers boondocking on site. Glen Rose, Stephenville 10-30 minutes away. Cabins and Airbnbs available. Book early.
logistics.food: Hico has BBQ and Tex-Mex. 'Great barbecue and Tex-Mex cuisine' - post-race is legendary.
logistics.packet_pickup: Pre-race in town with local vendors and food. Community-centric weekend vibe.
logistics.parking: Town-center event with plenty of space and festival atmosphere.

history.origin_story: Launched as a charity-focused, pro-heavy but community-driven event in 'cowboy town' Hico (associated with Billy the Kid). Flagship 150-mile race offered for FREE with donations to Hico first responders. In just a few years became a major pro tune-up for Unbound.
notable_moments: 2021: First year - rain but still fun
2022: 'The weather was hell' - 120°F tarmac, aid station ran out of water
2024: 'Just about perfect' - ideal Unbound tune-up weather
Pro winners: Justine Barrow, Julien Gagne
history.reputation: 'Go ride this race.' Free, community-driven, pro-heavy. The anti-corporate gravel race with legendary Texas hospitality and BBQ.

course_description.character: 'The scenery around Hico was stunning, adorned with wildflowers, and the gravel paths were as smooth as other riders had mentioned.' Difficulty is about relentless rollers, heat, and length - not technical terrain.

suffering_zones.label: Heat-Soaked Mid-Race
suffering_zones.desc: Heat typically spikes. Shade is scarce. If you've under-hydrated, you start to unravel here while still far from home.
suffering_zones.terrain_detail: Open ranch roads, no shade, heat builds

suffering_zones.label: After the 3B Climbs
suffering_zones.desc: This is where the 2022 aid station ran out of water. Riders waited 30+ minutes at 120°F. Even in good years, this is where under-prepared riders crack.

suffering_zones.label: Final Ascent to Hico
suffering_zones.desc: Rolling climb back into town. 7,884 ft of gain catches up to you here. Cramps and mental fatigue hit hardest in the final miles.

course_description.signature_challenge: The heat-soaked late race is the defining suffer zone. In normal years, cumulative rollers plus Texas heat near the end are what everyone talks about. In 2022, riders literally ran out of water.
